Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lid; interior glazed black with two pairs of faded added red bands; exterior, from centre: chain of buds with dots; three black bands; black-figure frieze: two warriors preserved, attacking to left (of left-hand figure only raised arm remaining with trace of added red on chiton; nude right-hand warrior with long hair and red helmet with added white dots on crest, scabbard on belt, greaves and Boeotian shield with white dots on rim and red on thunderbolt-style floral motif); ancient repair hole.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For a parallel regarding the floral decoration on the Boiotian shield, see CVA Villa Giulia, pl. 26, no. 5.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 342, no. B416)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0829) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 93, pl. II, no. 6)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
